description: Learned borrowing from Latin lacūna (“a ditch, pit; a hollow, cavity; a gap, defect”). Doublet of lacune and lagoon.

nouns.description: lacuna (plural lacunae or (obsolete) lacunæ or lacunas)

definitionGroups.group: (particularly anatomy) A small opening; a small pit or depression, especially in bone.

entries.meaning: (microscopy) A space visible between cells, allowing free passage of light.

definitionGroups.group: A small blank space; a gap or vacancy; a hiatus.

entries.meaning: An absent part, especially in a book or other piece of writing, often referring to an ancient manuscript or similar.
examples: Long lacunae in this inscription make interpretation difficult.

entries.meaning: Any gap, break, hole, or lack in a set of things; something missing.
(translation studies) A language gap, which occurs when there is no direct translation in the target language for a lexical term found in the source language.
